questions.question: Question 1: The most calorically dense macronutrient is
questions.explanation:
Fat is the most calorically dense macronutrient providing approximately 9 kcal/g. The nutrients that provide energy intake in the child’s diet are referred to as macronutrients. They 
include the following: • Fats (9 kcal/g) • Carbohydrates (4 kcal/g) • Proteins (4 kcal/g) The main dietary sources of fat are as follows: • For infants: human milk/formula • For older children: fat from animal products, vegetable oils, and margarine.

to restrict the dietary intake of saturated fat to less than

of total energy intake. Current dietary guidelines for children and adolescents: • Total fat should account for <30% of total daily energy • Saturated fat less than 10% of total daily energy • Dietary cholesterol <300 mg/day • No trans-fat

questions.question:
Question 3: Your school friend, the mother of a four-year-old child gives you a casual call. She had 
recently noticed an ad on margarine being a better alternative over butter/ghee and wishes to 
seek your opinion about adding it to her son's diet. What percentage of total daily energy 
requirement in children can come from margarine?
questions.explanation:
Margarine and other hydrogenated oils are trans fat. Trans fat is not recommended in children 
according to current dietary guidelines. Current dietary guidelines for children and adolescents: • Total fat should account for <30% of total daily energy • Saturated fat less than 10% of total daily energy • Dietary cholesterol <300 mg/day • No trans-fat

questions.question:
Question 4: 101 
Sold by @itachibot A newborn baby is ready to be discharged. As a part of your discharge advice, for how many 
months would you recommend exclusive breastfeeding?
questions.explanation:
Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for 6 months. Complementary foods rich in iron and other micronutrients should be introduced at about 6 
months of age. Breastfeeding should continue for at least the first year.

questions.question:
Question 5: You are taking a neonatal case for presentation during your postings. The mother tells you 
that the child is exclusively breastfed. Which of the following is least likely to corroborate 
with this history of being exclusively breastfed?
questions.explanation:
Exclusively breastfed infants are least likely to have evening colic. The incidence of diarrhoea, 
allergy to bovine milk, and atopic eczema are least reported in exclusively breastfed infants. Option A: Vitamin K content of milk is low and may contribute to hemorrhagic disease of 
the newborn. Option B: Breast milk contains inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase and enhances absorption of 
bilirubin from the gut. This leads to the development of breast milk jaundice. Option C: During the first few days, the breastfed infant has a black-green coloured stool. It 
changes to golden yellow by the end of the first week. 108 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following mothers can initiate breastfeeding?
questions.explanation:
The correct answer is 2 and 5 only. Breastfeeding is not contraindicated if the mother has 
hepatitis B infection or if she is a chronic smoker. Infants born to an HbsAg positive mother routinely receive hepatitis B immunoglobulin and 
hepatitis B vaccine. So, a delay in the initiation of breastfeeding is not required. Alcohol consumption and smoking are NOT contraindications of breastfeeding. However, 
smoking and alcohol consumption should be discouraged. Note: In a mother with untreated, active tuberculosis: • Temporarily withhold breastfeeding but can feed with expressed breastmilk • Resume breastfeeding once she has been adequately treated for 2 weeks and is no longer

questions.question:
Question 7: As a part of your neonatal rotation, you are asked to assess the adequacy of breastfeeding and 
breastfeeding techniques in a primi mother. Which of the following would be an indicator of 
inadequate breastfeeding in the neonate?

options.a: Baby sleeping for 2-3 hours after feed

questions.explanation:
Weight loss of >7-10% of birth weight is an indicator of inadequate breastfeeding in a neonate. Indicators of inadequate breastfeeding in the newborn: • Weight loss >7-10 % of birth weight • Lethargy (sleeping longer than 2–3 hours) • Delayed passage of stools (Less than 4 times/day) • Decreased urine output (urinating less than 5–7 times/day) • Hypernatremic dehydration • Inconsolable crying and increased hunger 109 
Sold by @itachibot Insufficient milk intake may be caused by insufficient milk production, failure of established 
breastfeeding, and health conditions in the infant that prevent proper breast stimulation. Breastfed neonates usually feed 8–12 times a day, with a minimum of 8 times per day. However, 
the neonate should be breastfed only on demand.

questions.question: Question 8: For how long can freshly expressed breastmilk be stored at room temperature?
questions.explanation:
Expressed breast milk can be stored at room temperature for 6-8 hours. Note: This is a controversial question. A difference of opinion among authors is noted regarding the refrigeration of expressed breast 
milk. Nelson's (21st ed, page 324) mentions that breast milk can be refrigerated and used within 
48 hours and frozen for around 6 months. However, AIIMS in collaboration 
with WHO recommends that breast milk can be refrigerated up to 24 hours and frozen at -20 
degree C for about 3 months. Expressed breast milk

Question 9: Shrija, a working mother planning to resume her work wishes to know more about expressed 
breast milk. Within how many hours would you advise her to use the refrigerated expressed 
breast milk?
questions.explanation:
Breast milk stored in the refrigerator should be used within 24 hours. Refrigerated or frozen milk should be thawed rapidly by holding under running tepid water and 
used completely within 24 h after thawing. Milk should never be microwaved. Note: This is a controversial question. A difference of opinion among authors is noted regarding the refrigeration of expressed breast 
milk. Nelson's (21st ed, page 324) mentions that breast milk can be refrigerated and used within 
48 hours and frozen for around 6 months. However, AIIMS in collaboration with

questions.question:
Question 10: An anxious new mother feeding her child with expressed breastmilk (EBM) feels that the 
consistency and colour of her milk have changed recently. She adds that when she expresses 
breastmilk, the colour and consistency of the first portion and the ending portion is 
completely different and that she is worried about the same. Which statement is not true 
about different breast milk?

options.b: Mature milk is thicker with all the essential nutrients for growth
options.c: Foremilk is watery and is rich in proteins and sugar
options.d: Hindmilk is richer in fat and provides more energy

questions.explanation:
Mature milk is thinner (not thicker) with all essential nutrients for growth. Various transitional forms of breastmilk: Colostrum • In the initial 3 to 4 days • Small quantity, thick, and yellow in colour • A large number of antibodies, immune component cells; and vitamins A, D, E, and K. Transitional milk • Secreted after 3 to 4 days until 2 weeks • Immunoglobulin and protein content decreases, while the fat and sugar content increases. Mature milk • Follows transitional milk. • Thinner and more watery. • Contains all the nutrients essential for the optimal growth of the baby. Foremilk • Secreted at the start of the feed • Watery and rich in proteins, sugar, vitamins, minerals, and water that quenches the baby’s 
thirst. Hindmilk • Comes towards the end of the feed • Provides more energy and a sense of satiety and it is richer in fat. Preterm milk • Milk of mother who delivers before 37 weeks. • Contains more proteins, sodium, iron, immunoglobins, and calories as per the requirement of 
the preterm infant. The given image shows watery foremilk and hindmilk which is rich in fat. 111 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: A 2-month-old child is brought to your OPD with complaints of diarrhoea. The mother wants 
to know if she should continue breastfeeding. Which of these components in breast milk, 
beneficial in intestinal cell maturation and repair, prompt you to advise her to continue 
breastfeeding?
questions.explanation:
The epidermal growth factor present in breastmilk helps in intestinal cell maturation and repair. 
This is why mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding in an infant affected with diarrhoea. 
It is also beneficial in luminal surveillance. Lactoferrin (Option A) helps in immunomodulation, iron chelation, antimicrobial action. It is also 
an antiadhesive and trophic for intestinal growth. Para-aminobenzoic acid (Option C) is present in low levels and offers protection against 
plasmodium. Glutathione peroxidase (Option D) prevents lipid oxidation.

questions.question:
Question 14: A young working mother wants to add formula feeds to the diet of her 5-month-old child as 
she would be unable to breastfeed her baby frequently and satiate her. Which of the following 
fatty acid should the mother look for in the formula to ensure optimal brain development in 
the child?
questions.explanation:
Docosahexenoic acid (DHA) and arachidonic acid (ARA), both play an important role in the 
growth and CNS development in babies. DHA and ARA are essential poly unsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) present in breast milk. Both are essential for cognition functions, visual acuity, and immune responses. They have 
optimal effects on brain development when included together, in efficacious levels, in an infant's 
diet. Almost all infant formulae are now fortified with pre-formed DHA and ARA. It is advisable that all infants upto 6 months of age are to be exclusively breastfed and not formula 
fed. However, in unavoidable situations such as lactation failure or maternal infections where 
breastfeeding is contraindicated, the use of a formula feed that contains both DHA and ARA is 
recommended. Other options: • Eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and Linolenic acid are other essential fatty acids that are present in 
breast milk. 113 
Sold by @itachibot • These are required for the overall protection of the cardiovascular system as well as to reduce 
systemic inflammation.

questions.question: Question 15: Breast milk is superior to cow’s milk because

options.c: Casein is 60% of the protein content
options.d: Whey is 70% of the protein content

questions.explanation:
Whey constitutes 70-80% of breast milk's protein content. The Whey: Casein ratio in human milk 
fluctuates between 70:30 and 80:20. This ratio is 20:80 in cow's milk. The high fraction of soluble 
whey protein in breast milk makes it easily digestible. The predominant whey protein is -lactalbumin in human milk and -globulin in cow milk. 
Human milk contains amino acids like taurine and cysteine (lacking in cow’s milk), which are 
necessary for neurotransmission and neuromodulation. Breast milk is rich in polyunsaturated fat (not saturated fat), which is necessary for 
myelination. Human breast milk is generally rich in oleic acid and linoleic acid. Sodium concentration is not high in breast milk. It has a low osmolality, and hence, the solute 
load on the kidneys is low. Differences between human milk and cow's milk are shown below: Nutrient

questions.question:
Question 17: 105 
Sold by @itachibot An exclusively breastfed neonate in his 4th week of life was found to be jaundiced. His stools 
are yellow and urine appears pale straw, he is otherwise well. A provisional diagnosis of 
breastmilk jaundice is made. Which of the following is false about this condition?

options.b: Some babies need treatment with phototherapy
options.d: It is common in the second week of life

questions.explanation:
Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in breast milk jaundice. Mothers are advised to continue 
breastfeeding at frequent intervals. Breastmilk jaundice is seen in about 2–4% of exclusively breastfed babies. There is significant 
unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 2–3 weeks. This may be 
caused by the breast milk that might contain -glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal 
bilirubin and promotes its absorption and other inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase. Persistently 
high bilirubin levels may require changing from breast milk to infant formula for 24–48 h and/or 
treatment with phototherapy, without cessation of breastfeeding. Breastfeeding jaundice (BFJ) It is an early-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants. Occurs in the 1st week 
after birth (usually appears after 24 - 72 hours of birth). It is due to decreased milk intake with 
dehydration and/or reduced caloric intake. The treatment would include continuing breastfeeding 
and supplementation with formula feeds if needed.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 26-year-old nursing mother presents with fever and pain in her left breast. She has had 
difficulty with breastfeeding previously, and now examination reveals her left breast is warm, 
red, swollen, and painful to palpation. She was started on dicloxacillin. What advice should be 
given to the mother regarding breastfeeding?

options.b: Continue feeding from both the breasts
options.c: Continue feeding from only right breast
options.d: Continue feeding from only left breast

questions.explanation:
115 
Sold by @itachibot Lactational mastitis is not a contraindication to breastfeeding and the mother should continue 
feeding on both breasts. It is most commonly caused due to Staphylococcus aureus present in the infant's nasopharynx. 
Dicloxacillin is safe to be given in nursing mothers.

questions.question:
Question 19: Which of the following statements are true with respect to the WHO Baby-Friendly Hospital 
Initiative for small, sick, and preterm newborns (2020)?
questions.explanation:
Finger-feeding is optimally indicated for short-term use and may improve breastfeeding rates at 
discharge. It is indicated in neurologically compromised and preterm infants for a short period of 
time. Paladai feeding is indicated in preterm, late preterm, and term infants for supplementation. It is 
economic, cheap, and is easy to use and clean. It has a risk of aspiration and is a slower method of 
feeding. Feeding tubes- orogastric or nasogastric tubes are an efficient way of measuring intake. It is 
optimally used in very preterm infants with no suck-swallow-breathe coordination for long-term 
use. It requires frequent replacement. Bottle and teat feeding, though not recommended is an efficient way to feed. Slow-flow teats 
mimic breastfeeding and are preferred to rapid-flow teats. They allow overfeeding and there is a 
risk of aspiration. 116 
Sold by @itachibot Protein Energy Malnutrition
